‚Äâ SPR_COMBO[fr]c'est un labo d'analyse qui se charge de l'analyse de l'eau nous on √©tait pass√© par un labo agr√©e par l'ANSES parce que c'√©tait pour savoir si elle √©tait potable, dans ton cas ce n'est peut-√™tre pas obligatoire. en tout cas voila la liste: https://www.anses.fr/fr/content/liste-des-laboratoires-agrees-pour-le-controle-sanitaire-des-eaux je pr√©cise que la transmission depuis un autre chien √ßa peut se faire sans qu'il soit au contant direct de l'animal, par exemple pendant la balade si il renifle une trace d'urine d'un chien contamin√© (faut que ce soit humide, si c'est sec il y a peu de risque), ou si un autre chien est venu pisser chez vous. mais d'apr√®s ce que tu dis √ßa semble effectivement plausible et probable que ce soit une population de rongeur infect√©s, et si ton bassin est vecteur de transmission, on peut supposer que tous les animaux qui boivent dedans sont potentiellement contamin√©s. pour √©liminer le r√©servoir de la bact√©rie, il va malheureusement falloir te d√©barrasser de ces rongeurs. l'approche qui consiste √† les capturer et √† les soigner/vacciner parait irr√©alisable car co√ªteuse et pas pratique. √† moins qu'il existe un traitement oral que tu pourrais mettre dans des appats que tu diss√©mines un peu partout dans les environs. je sais qu'on a fait √ßa pour √©radiquer la rage chez les renards dans ma r√©gion.

‚Äâ And it comes to an end! After an incredible journey, I'm proud to share that I've officially graduated from HEC Paris, Master in Marketing! This past year has been a whirlwind of creativity, strategy, and growth ‚Äî and I've had the chance to work on unforgettable real-world projects with iconic brands: Parfums Christian Dior ‚Äì Designed a Gen Z fragrance collection and promotional plan. L'Or√©al x La Roche-Posay USA Bootcamp ‚Äì Built a product concept and 360¬∞ campaign for next-gen UV protection. Veepee ‚Äì Developed e-commerce strategies to engage younger audiences. McKinsey & Company ‚Äì Crafted consulting strategies for platform growth. DDB x Amazon ‚Äì Led a social media strategy to spotlight Amazon's sustainability efforts. Kering x DoDo Jewels ‚Äì Selected as finalists to present a 360¬∞ market expansion strategy for DoDo Jewels. Cartier ‚Äì Created storytelling and launch strategy for Cartier Home new collection. Our team won 1st placeü•á and was invited to a private Cartier piano concert. Another highlight: our London learning expedition, where we visited Burberry, Cartier, and Warner Bros. Discovery HQs, and connected with the HEC UK Alumni House. I was deeply inspired by the powerful voices of women leaders in marketing and luxury. To my incredible marketing crew ‚Äî thanks for all the brainstorms, good vibes, and late-night laughs. And to our amazing program directors Gachoucha Kretz, PhD and Marion BOUYOU ‚Äî thank you for crafting a journey that was both challenging and deeply rewarding. When I enrolled in this program, I never expected to grow this much ‚Äî but it truly prepared me to become a better marketing leader, with stronger creativity, strategic thinking, and empathy. I'm thrilled to share my next chapter: I'll be joining The Est√©e Lauder Companies Inc. Presidential Management Scholar Program in China, working in the Marketing department of Le Labo Fragrances ‚Äî a brand I deeply admire for its soul, storytelling, and slow beauty philosophy. On to the next adventure #HECParis #Marketing #Graduation #Luxury #Beauty #BrandStrategy #Storytelling #MarketingLeadership #WomenInMarketing

‚Äâ La Mort ? Pas pour tout le monde, voyons ! Ah, la mort‚Ä¶ cette grande √©galisatrice ! Ou du moins, c'est ce qu'on nous racontait avant que la science ne vienne mettre son grain de sel. Aujourd'hui, il est clair que face √† la grande faucheuse, nous ne sommes pas tous log√©s √† la m√™me enseigne. Et c'est tant mieux pour certains ! Th√©rapies de pointe : le luxe de l'immortalit√© Fini le temps des simples pilules et des rem√®des de grand-m√®re ! D√©sormais, les th√©rapies g√©niques sont l√† pour vous reprogrammer de A √† Z. Votre ADN est un peu fatigu√© ? Un petit coup de polish g√©n√©tique, et hop, vous voil√† comme neuf ! Bien s√ªr, cette customisation mol√©culaire a un co√ªt‚Ä¶ astronomique. La m√©decine de pr√©cision, elle, vous assure un traitement sur mesure, calibr√© au millim√®tre pr√®s selon votre patrimoine g√©n√©tique. Fini les t√¢tonnements, place √† l'efficacit√©‚Ä¶ pour ceux qui peuvent se l'offrir, bien entendu. Et les organes ? Cultivons-les ! Pourquoi attendre une greffe quand on peut avoir un foie flambant neuf, cultiv√© sur mesure dans un labo ultra-secret ? Quant aux interventions anti-√¢ge, elles promettent de vous faire sauter des d√©cennies d'un coup. Imaginez : prolonger votre jeunesse, conserver votre vitalit√©‚Ä¶ pendant que les autres comptent leurs rides et leurs cheveux blancs. C'est le prix √† payer pour ne pas vieillir, litt√©ralement. La surveillance high-tech : votre corps, un compte en banque Oubliez les visites chez le m√©decin tous les six mois. Avec les capteurs de derni√®re g√©n√©ration et les analyses √† domicile, votre corps devient une mine de donn√©es consultables en temps r√©el. La moindre petite anomalie est d√©tect√©e avant m√™me que vous n'ayez eu le temps de b√¢iller. Cela permet de prendre des mesures pr√©ventives imm√©diates ! Pendant que certains d√©couvrent leur maladie au stade terminal, d'autres la d√©jouent avant m√™me qu'elle ne pointe le bout de son nez. C'est √ßa, la proactivit√© de luxe ! Recherche priv√©e : quand le profit prolonge la vie Qui finance ces merveilles ? Les grandes entreprises et les philanthropes √©clair√©s, bien s√ªr ! Et comme ils ne font pas √ßa par charit√© ‚Äì ou du moins pas seulement ‚Äì, il est √©vident que le retour sur investissement passe avant tout. Les premiers servis ? Ceux qui ont le portefeuille le plus garni. Certains milliardaires se sont m√™me d√©j√† offert des th√©rapies exp√©rimentales pour la long√©vit√©, histoire de prendre de l'avance sur l'humanit√©. C'est le principe du "premier arriv√©, premier servi", mais avec la vie √©ternelle en jeu. Le "mode de vie optimis√©" : parce que la sant√©, √ßa se mange (cher) ! Pourquoi se contenter de courir un jogging quand on peut avoir un coach sportif d√©di√©, un chef personnel pr√©parant des repas bio sur mesure, et un nutritionniste qui vous dit quel est le petit doigt de pied que vous devez bouger pour prolonger votre existence ? Les nantis peuvent s'offrir un environnement sans pollution, √©viter les emplois stressants, et vivre dans une bulle de bien-√™tre qui maximise leurs chances de long√©vit√©. Pendant que les autres subissent la pollution et le stress du m√©tro-boulot-dodo, certains cultivent leur long√©vit√© comme un pr√©cieux jardin. Le capital humain et social : la richesse, √ßa se capitalise ! Et le clou du spectacle : en vivant plus longtemps et en meilleure sant√©, les riches peuvent continuer √† accumuler plus de richesse et de pouvoir. C'est un cercle vertueux (pour eux, s'entend) : plus vous √™tes riche, plus vous vivez longtemps et en bonne sant√©, plus vous devenez riche. C'est ce qu'on appelle l'optimisation du capital humain, o√π l'esp√©rance de vie devient un actif financier. Alors, la mort est-elle vraiment aveugle ? Apparemment, elle a plut√¥t tendance √† se pencher du c√¥t√© de ceux qui peuvent se permettre d'ignorer ses avances. Une chose est s√ªre : pour prolonger l'existence, il va falloir allonger les billets. Et si l'acc√®s √† la vie √©ternelle d√©pend de votre compte en banque, eh bien, nous ne sommes d√©cid√©ment pas tous √©gaux devant la fin ! N'est-ce pas une merveilleuse perspective pour l'avenir ?

‚Äâ Tinou Desch alors sur ma p√©riode de pr√©sence lors de mes ann√©es "l'enfantement" j'ai atteint mes objectifs professionnels. Elle a ete un peu d√©go√ªt√©e Les jours enfants malades ne sont pas pr√©sents dans tous les contrats sauf erreur de ma part il n'y a pas d'articles dans le code du travail s'y r√©f√©rant. ‚Äâ Juliette Has a Gun - Pear Inc ‚Ä¢ Smells like juicy, ripe pear and musk. Really easy reach scent for me year round but it shines in the heat. Svensk Parfym - Prakt ‚Ä¢ Smells like gooseberries, fresh air and childhood. Juicy, fresh and brilliant in the spring and summer. Dolce & Gabana - L'imperatrice ‚Ä¢ A unique fruity scent in that kiwi/rhubarb freshness. Doesn't last particularly long but smells awesome. Giorgio Armani - Ocean di Gioia ‚Ä¢ Smells like sweet pear and salty air. Really good refreshing scent. Valentino - Donna Born in Roma Gold ‚Ä¢ Smells like a pretty girl on a tropical vacation. It's primarily gardenia and the citrus and coconut just round it out. Le Labo - Another 13 ‚Ä¢ Smells like the sweat of a sexy person to me, which may not sound appealing but it really is. It's sexy but in a light and airy way. Andrea Mack - Ceramic ‚Ä¢ Smells like fabric softener. Slightly sweet, clean and very pleasant. DS & Durga - Debaser ‚Ä¢ Bright, juicy fig and notes of green notes come across the most. It feels sophisticated to me. Stephane Humbert Lucas - Pink Boa ‚Ä¢ This is a sweltering hot weather scent. It's really cooling and refreshing, like a pink G&T or shower gel. Vilhelm Parfumerie - Dear Polly ‚Ä¢ Smells like green apple and black tea. Really fresh but not super long lasting. Narcotica - Narco Oasis ‚Ä¢ This is a "I'm a gourmand girl but it's too hot to smell like vanilla cake right now" scent. It's sweet, juicy, delicious but because it's passionfruity it comes across lighter and not cloying By Kilian - Flower of Immortality ‚Ä¢ Subtle, juicy peach and delicate floral. . Honourable mention here to PDM - Valaya and Meliora which feel similar to me, also JHAG - Magnolia Bliss. All clean, juicy fruity florals. J-Scent - Yawahada ‚Ä¢ The only milky scent I've found that works in heat without being too thick. The pear is delicate and juicy and the milk note is quiet but adds a lovely creaminess. Jeroboam - Floro ‚Ä¢ Fruity, musky. Similar to Valaya but pineapple and apple instead of peach. Phlur - Father Figure. Light fresh dewy fig. Masculine leaning. Vilhelm Parfumerie - Opus Kore ‚Ä¢ Acai berry note, really juicy and kind of reminds me of shampoo. Atelier des Ors - Pink Me Up ‚Ä¢ Date night rose for warmer months. Dark and jammy but not too heavy. Maison Crivelli - Rose Saltifolia ‚Ä¢ Salty sweet fresh rose. Beautiful daytime at the beach restaurant scent. Bjork and Berries - Never Spring ‚Ä¢ Reminds me of lemonade in the opening. Sweet and citrusy. Dior - Dioriviera ‚Ä¢ Light, dewy airy fig and rose. Malin&Goetz - Strawberry ‚Ä¢ Woody fresh, like a field of strawberries or taking a big sniff of an unripe strawberry. BTSO - Fig Porn ‚Ä¢ Juicy Juicy fig. Ellis Brooklyn - Miami Nectar ‚Ä¢ Pi√±a colada. Jovoy - Musc Pallas ‚Ä¢ Beautiful airy clean skin scent. Ariana Grande - Thank U, Next 2.0 ‚Ä¢ Apple juice. Ariana Grande - God is a Woman ‚Ä¢ Pear candy. Xerjoff - Dama Bianca ‚Ä¢ Powdery sweet girly floral Dries Van Noten - Vanille Camouflage ‚Ä¢ Green figgy scent with a lovely cool vanilla dry down I could probably list a million more....

‚Äâ Additional comment to elaborate on my choices (not that anyone asked...) Debut is very green, something young people can wear that doesn't scream VS body sprays. Something that says "Please take me seriously, I can be a grown woman" and should be very accessible. I think Elizabeth Arden Green Tea fits that. Its more solar counterpart with Sunflowers fits Beautiful Eyes EP. Aside from the name 'Love Story' being fitting, I think it's a very great scent that's very clean and palatable to many -- which is what Fearless, being her breakthrough album, represents. The top notes are still very bright and citrusy, which represents her youth very well. YSL Libre is kind of a more mature version of it, still white florals being the main accords, but it has that richer vanilla working in the back. I have never had the chance to smell Wonderstruck, but I thought it would be the best choice given it was that era. Based on its notes, it's mostly fruity. So for Speak Now TV, I chose something that was also fruity, but a bit more sophisticated, and that was Chance Eau Tendre. The color of the perfume itself also fits very well with the TV tutu dress photoshoot. For Red, Very Good Girl's notes are litchi, red currant, and rose - which are mostly red. And the bottle design? "He didn't like it when I wore high heels..." I think Red is a great album navigating trying to be more mature, but also holding on to your youth. There's a freshness to Very Good Girl thanks to its fruity top notes, but a grounded maturity in its vanilla and vetiver finish. For the TV, I chose Girl of Now which is very almond-y (and a great scent for fall!) , but its tonka bean/cashmere base notes feel like a more refined version. It's kind of like comparing OG ATW and the 10MVTV. 1989 is Le Labo Santal 33, which is NY in a bottle. The TV is Bois Imperial, which is the now more bougie NY scent in a bottle. Still on a santal-related note, Taylor was supposedly confirmed to use TF Santal Blush during rep era. I personally love spicy woody scents, and it has a nice intrigue to it, but the middle floral notes can still make it light enough to wear. Lover is Miss Dior. A nice sweet romantic scent (peach x roses), with a lot of sensuality going on in the back (tonka bean, benzoin). I chose La Vie Est Belle for the LFP which is a lot sweeter, but has that same sensual floral going for it. folklore I smell as something more woody, but still light. I think Mojave Ghost has that balance. evermore with TF Tobacco Vanille (which Taylor also uses) still has that woody accord, but evokes more smokiness. Midnights I think is perfectly encapsulated by Black Opium. It has that cozy vanilla - coffee scent that will keep you up and fades into a woody patchouli. Patchouli is associated with masking the smell of weed, can be an essential oil or incense. "Cleaning incense off your vinyl shelf..." TTPD is Mugler Angel because she is an absolute mess. If you look at the notes, you're just like, what the heck is going on here. She's polarizing, but she's literally a star. The bottle itself is a star. But she's endured decades and is still considered a classic. The Anthology to me evokes a lot of introspection, with many of the songs told in the lenses of hindsight. To me, the songs are like stories I would share with someone over drinks in a booth. Jazz Club hits that sweet-smoky scent that makes you feel like you're reminiscing over hazy memories. Lastly, Christmas is the smell of freshly baked cookies, and Vanille 44 gets it perfectly. Other gourmands could work too. (omg this is so long im so sorry)

‚Äâ Est√©e Lauder's Strategic Shift: How International Diversification and Supply Chain Overhaul Fuel Growth Potential Est√©e Lauder Companies (NYSE: EL) has experienced a notable stock surge in June 2025, driven by renewed investor optimism around its strategic pivot toward international diversification and supply chain optimization. Despite a 10.34% year-to-date decline, the stock's 5.66% monthly rise (as of June 15) signals a growing belief that the cosmetics giant is navigating its way toward sustainable growth. This article examines how the company's ‚ÄúBeauty Reimagined‚Äù vision‚Äîfocused on global market penetration and operational efficiency‚Äîis reshaping its trajectory. The Catalyst: A Strategic Rebalance The surge began after Deutsche Bank upgraded EL to ‚ÄúBuy‚Äù with a $95 price target, citing progress in international growth strategies and supply chain improvements. The analyst highlighted the company's efforts to expand in high-growth markets, reduce costs through its Profit Recovery and Growth Plan (PRGP), and leverage innovation to capture new consumer segments. International Diversification: Beyond Asia's Challenges While Asia/Pacific sales fell 11% in Q2 due to softness in China and Korea, Est√©e Lauder is repositioning its geographic strategy to mitigate regional risks: - China: Gained prestige beauty market share in Makeup (Est√©e Lauder) and Skin Care (La Mer), with The Ordinary's planned entry into mainland China (February 2025) targeting affordable luxury. - Japan: Le Labo's Fragrance dominance and La Mer's Skin Care leadership solidified its #1 Fragrance ranking. - EMEA: Fragrance sales surged with Le Labo's global store expansion (over 20 new locations) and the Paris Fragrance Atelier launch. - Americas: The Ordinary's expansion into Amazon's U.S. Premium Beauty Store and Clinique's Almost Lipstick success showcased resilience in mature markets. Supply Chain Optimization: Turning Costs into Catalysts The PRGP, now expanded to cover $1.2‚Äì1.6 billion in restructuring charges, is a bold move to streamline operations and fund growth: - Procurement Consolidation: Negotiating better supplier terms to reduce costs. - Zero-Waste Supply Chains: Improving demand forecasting and inventory management to cut excess stock. - Outsourcing Non-Core Services: Freeing resources for consumer-facing initiatives. By 2027, these efforts aim to deliver $800‚Äì1.0 billion in annual cost savings, which will directly fund marketing, innovation, and geographic expansion. Product Innovation: Fueling Long-Term Growth Est√©e Lauder is betting on biotechnology and niche brands to drive differentiation: - The Ordinary: Its disruptive anti-aging GF 15% Solution (priced at $15) targets Gen Z/ Millennials, with planned expansions into Thailand and China. - Le Labo: Fragrance sales grew 2% globally, fueled by hits like Osaka-inspired scents and freestanding stores. - MIT Collaboration: A BioTech Hub in Belgium aims to accelerate breakthroughs in skincare and haircare. Risks and Reality Checks While the strategy is promising, challenges remain: - Asia Travel Retail Slump: A ‚Äústrong double-digit decline‚Äù in Q2, driven by Korea's regulatory shifts and China's post-pandemic spending lag. - Brand Impairments: $861 million in goodwill write-downs (TOM FORD, Too Faced) signal overvaluation risks in underperforming brands. - Near-Term Earnings Pressure: Q3 2025 forecasts a 79‚Äì69% EPS drop due to restructuring and Asia weakness. Investment Thesis: Buy with Caution Est√©e Lauder's stock surge reflects investor confidence in its long-term strategy, but valuation discipline is key: - Upside: If Asia travel retail recovers and cost savings materialize, margins could rebound toward its 15‚Äì20% target. - Downside: Prolonged macroeconomic headwinds or brand underperformance could delay recovery. Historical performance, however, suggests caution. A backtest of a strategy buying EL following positive quarterly earnings surprises and holding for 30 trading days (2020‚Äì2025) revealed an average annual return of 1.53%, with a maximum drawdown of -15.21%. The strategy underperformed its benchmark by 68.41%, highlighting high volatility and poor risk-adjusted returns. These results underscore the need for patience: Recommendation: - Buy: For investors with a 3‚Äì5 year horizon, willing to tolerate near-term volatility. The $95 price target (Deutsche Bank) implies a ~40% upside from current levels. - Hold: For shorter-term players, given the Q3 earnings risks and geopolitical uncertainties. Final Take Est√©e Lauder's pivot to strategic diversification and operational rigor positions it to capitalize on global beauty demand. While execution risks persist, the company's focus on innovation, cost discipline, and niche markets could turn this surge into a sustained climb. As the Motley Fool noted, it's not a ‚Äútop pick‚Äù‚Äîbut for those willing to bet on its turnaround, the potential rewards may outweigh the risks. Stay informed, and invest wisely. ‚Äâ At a pristine, multimillion-dollar lab on the Manhattan waterfront, just down the street from a men's homeless shelter and the medical examiner's office, a slice of summer plum is being converted into fragrance code. This is the work of Osmo, a fragrance tech startup claiming to build artificial olfactory intelligence. Osmo has parlayed this innovation into offering turnkey fragrance compounding that promises a 48-hour sample turnaround from initial client prompt. In the time it takes your Amazon Prime order to arrive, you may now order a custom perfume. Traditionally, creating a fragrance isn't fast. After a client provides a brief ‚Äî usually a mood, memory, or concept ‚Äî a perfumer begins weeks or months of formulation trials, compounding and revising dozens of modifications, or ‚Äúmods.‚Äù Each must settle before it can be evaluated for balance, projection, and drydown. Raw materials often need years of cultivation. Bottling, regulatory reviews, packaging, and testing follow. From concept to shelf, a single perfume can take six to 18 months ‚Äî even longer in luxury. And like fine wines, fragrance materials vary with climate concerns. One year's yield will not smell like the next one, or the one before. Osmo built its shiny new empire, hoping to disrupt the fragrance market, on its digitization of a plum and the speed with which it can analyze and transport odor molecules. Its goal: to disrupt the fragrance market with AI-powered scent creation. I first encountered the smell of this ‚Äúdigitized plum‚Äù at a scent conference, handed to me by an independent perfumer like contraband. A group gathered around the blotter, whispering: it was too medicinal, too clean. ‚ÄúWhere's the bruising, the rot ‚Äî the heat?‚Äù someone asked. ‚ÄúWhere's the craftsmanship? Where's the perfumer?‚Äù I've judged hundreds of perfumes blindly for international fragrance awards and worked on machine learning systems at tech startups. I know the pull of scent well formulated ‚Äî and the allure of tech's frictionless promises. To me, the plum smelled real, if strangely large and genetically modified. I could smell it from yards away ‚Äî James and the Giant Plum, rolling toward me from a Roald Dahl retelling. But the question hanging in the air was larger than a fruit: as AI enters perfumery, are we expanding access to beauty ‚Äî or automating the soul out of it? AI isn't coming to fragrance ‚Äî it's already here, and in most things that the average consumer smells. The four fragrance conglomerates responsible for most of what the world smells ‚Äî DSM-Firmenich, Givaudan, IFF, and Symrise ‚Äî all integrate AI into their pipelines. Givaudan's Carto system helps perfumers refine formulas. DSM-Firmenich's EmotiON claims to produce scents that improve well-being. These systems are used not just in product labs but in fragrance education worldwide. The hairsprays and soaps and cleaning products and luxury fragrances that line your shelves ‚Äî all of these have been touched by these four powerhouses of perfume and, so too, the AI involved in their processes. The principal perfumer at DSM-Firmenich, Frank Voelkl, who is behind the fragrances that make up so much of our current odor aura ‚Äî Le Labo's Santal 33, Glossier's You, Tom Ford's Tuscan Leather ‚Äî uses AI on a daily basis as part of his creative process. ‚ÄúWhen I began as a perfumer, there were no emails ‚Äî we were still communicating with fax machines, you know. I started by handwriting my formulas. The beauty of AI is that it manages regulatory concerns, issues around stability, phasing, performance. These tools are tremendously helpful in resolving technical issues so I can focus much more on the creative part, which requires my imagination, emotions, intuition, and the human factor. It's like a clerk.‚Äù Heather, a perfumer-in-training in France, tells me AI use is now standard among her peers. ‚ÄúMost, if not all my classmates, have used AI for every project or question. Gen Z uses it like an operating tool ‚Äî older generations use it like a browser.‚Äù When Heather says Gen Z uses AI ‚Äúlike an operating tool,‚Äù she means they rely on it as a functional extension of the creative process ‚Äî from selecting materials to refining accords. Older generations, meanwhile, still treat it as a secondary resource, like a search engine or inspiration board. For new creators, AI isn't just assistance ‚Äî it's infrastructure, taking over essential parts of the perfumery processes. Pierre Vouard, a professor at FIT, sees both opportunity and loss: ‚ÄúCompounding by hand, knowing the exact amount of each material, weighing it yourself ‚Äî that's going to disappear. But is it crucial?‚Äù He knows AI is used in his own classroom. ‚ÄúPerhaps this will be true democratization of fragrance because it drastically reduces the cost of creating one. But it does make you ask: Where's the craftsmanship? Where's the perfumer?‚Äù ‚ÄúThere've only been about 100,000 fragrances ever made....

‚Äâ The global Luxury Perfume Market, long anchored in heritage, exclusivity, and in-store experiences, is undergoing a digital transformation. As consumer behavior shifts toward convenience and personalization, luxury fragrance brands are increasingly leveraging e-commerce, subscription services, and digital marketing strategies to capture a broader and more diverse audience. This evolution is not only revitalizing legacy brands but also giving rise to independent perfume houses with cult followings. Rise of Online Platforms and E-Commerce Channels Traditionally, luxury perfumes were purchased through upscale department stores and boutique outlets. However, the COVID-19 pandemic accelerated a trend that had already begun‚Äîshopping for high-end fragrances online. Today, consumers are more comfortable purchasing luxury items through digital platforms, even without sampling them physically beforehand. E-commerce now accounts for a growing share of perfume sales, and luxury brands are responding by enhancing their digital storefronts with interactive features, detailed product descriptions, and high-quality visuals. Brands like Chanel, Dior, and Tom Ford have invested heavily in their online presence, offering virtual consultations and online-exclusive fragrance collections. Third-party platforms such as Sephora, Net-a-Porter, and Farfetch also serve as critical digital touchpoints, providing access to a wide range of luxury scents for global consumers. In markets like the United States, China, and the Middle East, younger consumers‚Äîparticularly Millennials and Gen Z‚Äîare driving this online shift. These tech-savvy customers expect seamless browsing, secure transactions, and fast delivery, all of which are now becoming standard offerings from luxury fragrance retailers. Subscription Models Bring Personalization and Discovery Subscription models have added a layer of innovation to the luxury perfume space, appealing to consumers who value variety and personalized experiences. Companies like Scentbird, Luxury Scent Box, and Sniph are disrupting the traditional buying process by offering curated monthly fragrance selections delivered to customers' doorsteps. These services allow consumers to experiment with designer and niche fragrances without committing to a full-sized bottle, often priced between $100 and $300. By using quizzes and algorithms, subscription platforms tailor offerings to individual preferences, such as floral, woody, or oriental scent profiles. Luxury brands are beginning to collaborate with subscription services as a way to introduce new launches and limited-edition fragrances to targeted customer segments. In some cases, consumers who discover a new favorite through a subscription service go on to purchase full-sized versions through brand websites, closing the loop between exploration and conversion. This model is also sustainable and consumer-friendly, reducing fragrance waste and enabling brands to test new product concepts with minimal risk. Social Media Campaigns Drive Brand Storytelling and Engagement In today's competitive landscape, having a premium product is only part of the equation‚Äîeffective storytelling and emotional resonance are equally essential. Social media platforms, particularly Instagram, TikTok, and YouTube, have become powerful tools for fragrance brands to connect with audiences in more intimate and creative ways. High-quality visuals, aspirational videos, and behind-the-scenes content help convey the craftsmanship, ingredients, and brand heritage associated with each scent. Influencers and content creators play a pivotal role in this process, offering authentic reviews and unboxing experiences that resonate with younger consumers. A 2024 report by Euromonitor noted that nearly 60% of Gen Z perfume buyers discover new fragrances via influencer content and social media advertising. Brands like Le Labo, Byredo, and Maison Francis Kurkdjian have successfully cultivated loyal online communities by emphasizing authenticity, artistry, and clean ingredients. These niche brands often rely more on digital campaigns and word-of-mouth than on traditional advertising, highlighting how social media can level the playing field between established and emerging players. In addition to organic posts and influencer collaborations, luxury fragrance houses are investing in paid social media campaigns using targeted ads to reach specific demographics, based on age, gender, and scent preferences. Augmented reality filters, immersive storytelling, and interactive polls are increasingly used to engage consumers and boost brand recall. Data-Driven Strategies Enhance Consumer Experience As luxury brands deepen their digital footprint, the use of customer data and analytics is becoming crucial. From tracking online behavior to understanding purchasing patterns, data helps brands refine product offerings, personalize marketing messages, and optimize the timing of promotions. AI and machine learning are being applied to improve scent recommendations, identify trends, and streamline inventory. Some brands are even experimenting with virtual scent experiences using scent-matching quizzes and AR-enhanced features that mimic the olfactory experience of testing a perfume in-store. Luxury brands are also integrating loyalty programs and exclusive access to incentivize repeat purchases and deepen customer relationships. For instance, some offer early access to new releases or personalized engraving services to loyal online customers. Conclusion The luxury perfume market is no longer confined to glass display cases and exclusive brick-and-mortar boutiques. Online platforms, subscription models, and social media campaigns are transforming the way consumers discover, experience, and purchase fragrances. While the essence of luxury‚Äîquality, craftsmanship, and exclusivity‚Äîremains unchanged, the pathways through which these values are communicated and delivered are being redefined. This digital shift offers tremendous growth opportunities for established brands and newcomers alike. By embracing innovation without compromising their core identity, luxury perfume brands are well-positioned to captivate the next generation of fragrance enthusiasts across the globe.

‚Äâ ‚ÄúWill the girl who I just met at the perfume store please comment the perfume you recommended,‚Äù wrote Chappell Roan on Instagram last month. ‚ÄúYou said it smelled like lipstick.‚Äù The post went viral and the scent ‚Äì Girl of the Year by the Los Angeles perfume house Thin Wild Mercury ‚Äì instantly sold out. It's hard to think of a more appropriate perfume for the performer. The house describes it as having ‚Äútop notes of lipstick and incense; middle notes of 'smoker's leather jacket' and a base of sandalwood, orris root and vintage fur‚Äù. The brand ‚Äì whose name is culled from a Bob Dylan quote ‚Äì is one of a growing set of perfumers reinventing scent for new fragrance fans. Like bedroom DJs or T-shirt screen-printers before them, they're changing the culture of an established industry. The global fragrance market is the biggest it has ever been and still growing; it is set to generate revenue of about ¬£45bn in 2025, according to Statista. The UK market alone reached ¬£1.74bn in 2024 and, if growth continues apace, will top ¬£2bn by 2029 according to a 2024 Mintel report. This growth is driven by gen Z and millennials, who have formed a unique relationship with fragrance due to social media and Covid isolation ‚Äì PerfumeTok drove 45% of social media scent sales in the US by 2023. Instead of a dab behind the ear, they prefer scent layering ‚Äì wearing two or more perfumes at the same time ‚Äì and scent wardrobing (matching fragrances to different occasions). Eighty-three per cent of gen Z wear fragrance as often as three times a week, according to a recent report by Circana. Perfume took off, somewhat unexpectedly, during lockdown, says Suzy Nightingale of the podcast On the Scent. ‚ÄúIt was expected the fragrance market would fall, but it boomed,‚Äù says Nightingale, an award-winning perfume blogger. ‚ÄúPeople discovered they could punctuate their day with moments of difference ‚Äì travel with their noses, revel in nostalgia or excite their senses with novelty. I think that was when people realised it's not about 'attracting a partner' or having a signature scent ‚Äì if it ever was. It's donning an invisible cloak of protection, empowering yourself.‚Äù Successful perfume influencers play a key role in the storytelling side of these products. Theatrical and charismatic TikTokkers such as @professorperfume and @jeremyfragrance explain new scents so vividly that their followers sometimes buy without smelling the perfume first. They spin tales of the weird girls and confident boys who wear these scents; PerfumeTok influences 66% of gen Z purchases. Teenage boys have become surprising cognoscenti when it comes to luxury aftershave. The TikTok term for scent layering in this age group is ‚Äúsmellmaxxing‚Äù, a buzzword that became so prevalent that the New York Times defined it last year as a ‚Äúterm for enhancing one's musk‚Äù. According to a 2025 US trend report by Piper Sandler, teenagers are spending more money across beauty categories in general, but fragrance has grown the most ‚Äì up 22% year on year. On a recent visit to Bloom Perfumery, a boutique selling independent and niche fragrances in the UK, I watched a boy who couldn't have been older than 16 chat about cologne with an assistant twice his age with a genuinely inspiring level of passion and sophistication, beaming through his braces as he discussed smoky notes. ‚ÄúThere's been a lot of pearl-clutching commentary worrying about how much [teenagers] spend,‚Äù says Nightingale. ‚ÄúBut if you actually bother to talk to the younger generations thronging the halls of perfumeries from Boots to the Black Hall of Harrods, you discover they're saving their pocket money ‚Äì sometimes for years ‚Äì and taking on part-time jobs to explore scent.‚Äù While previous generations were satisfied with scent juggernauts such as CK One, Le Male, Poison or Opium, an emerging group of ‚Äúfrag heads‚Äù wants more. The idea of personalising your scent ‚Äì smellmaxxing or scent layering ‚Äì is key for them. Still, what 16-year-old can afford to layer a ¬£90 Loewe scent with something marginally cheaper from Armani ‚Äì and to that end, how did such expensive scents become the norm? As luxury scents boomed post-pandemic, so too did dupes ‚Äì replicas of designer products. Offering luxury style at low prices, dupes feel more Robin Hood than guilty secret. Some new brands got their start providing vegan or cruelty-free alternatives to blockbuster fragrances, notably Eden Perfumes, a family-run business in Brighton now lauded for its own scents as much as its knockoffs. Meanwhile, the high street stepped up to do what it does best: producing designer style at affordable prices. The Zara perfume counter is currently the place to go if you want to smell like a million dollars for less than ¬£20. While logos and bottle designs are easy to trademark, you cannot trademark a scent nor patent a perfume recipe under UK law. Some dupes can be poorer quality than luxury brands, but they're safe as long as you use common sense. A trusted retailer will follow safety standards; an unknown one may not be as stringent. As well as dupes, ‚Äúniche perfumes‚Äù gained traction. While cosmetics giants such as Coty, Guerlain and Est√©e Lauder have dominated since the early 20th century, independent pioneers appeared who followed their instincts and taste rather than market research. Brands such as Le Labo, Sol de Janeiro and Byredo changed the game ‚Äì Le Labo's Santal 33 was the fashion circle's signature scent and a Santal 26 candle appeared in Beyonc√©'s Lemonade film in 2016. Victoria Beckham and Sienna Miller namechecked Byredo as their favourite perfumer. It is no wonder these brands have now been snapped up by LVMH and other conglomerates. More indie scents launched after lockdown, including complicated and counterintuitive fragrances. The idea of perfume as confrontational, confusing art grew. The Canadian brand Zoologist found fame for its award-winning Bee scent (notes of ginger syrup, royal jelly and broom) in 2020, as did Inexcusable Evil by the Romanian perfumer Toskovat, with its bouquet of bandages, blood and burnt flowers. This year brings Silver Haze from Alloy Studio, which evokes ‚Äúa backseat smoke session‚Äù and has notes of cannabis, chocolate powder and strawberries. Food-inspired fragrances are the latest perfume craze with scents like pretzels and cherries finding favour. Some fans went deep, obsessing over process, rarity or a unique note in a scent, discussing them like oenophiles on Reddit and dedicated scent chatrooms. Some turned to DIY, using Sam Macer's YouTube channel and forums such as Basenotes to swap tips on sourcing ingredients and aroma combinations. For a few, the hobby became a side hustle and finally a career....

‚Äâ Gracie Abrams is having a summer for the books. The 25-year-old singer-songwriter has spent the better part of 2025 on her Secret Of Us Tour which began last September, did her Glastonbury debut last weekend and today sees her opening for Noah Kahan at BST Hyde Park. ‚ÄúPlaying at Glastonbury on a Friday was such a privilege. It allowed me the time to lean in hard into the festival, which I did. That was intense and perfect for me in a great way, but it's a rarity,‚Äù she tells Bazaar on a sunny evening at the Broadwick, Soho. Abrams, whose first album, Minor, released in 2020, notes that her post-show rituals are often a lot more ‚Äúvanilla‚Äù. ‚ÄúIt's a quick shower and I'll get in the biggest clothes I have. I'll journal for a little bit or read something before I fall asleep,‚Äù she reflects. In between performing in ethereal ensembles by Chanel and Rodarte (barefoot, of course), for loyal fans who get teary-eyed by her melancho-pop sounds and vulnerable songwriting, Abrams has signed on to front Hourglass Cosmetics' new complexion campaign. Abrams' clean and polished signature make-up look ties in beautifully with Hourglass' range of your-skin-but-better concealers, bases and the new Illusion Priming Moisturiser. Ahead of her special appearance in Soho's The Vinyl Factory, Abrams sat down with Bazaar to share the heartfelt story behind her bob haircut, the signature scent that reminds her of home and her go-to blush combination. On her beauty philosophy‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI tend to feel the most beautiful when I have the least on my face and when I feel the most like myself. It's really just about what makes you feel like you. [With beauty] when you find the lane that makes sense for you, it's exciting and inspiring to explore it. My mum wasn't someone who wore a lot of make-up but when she did a red lip, or something extra, it always caught my attention. I also love Alexa Chung.‚Äù On her skincare routine‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúIn the morning, I use cold water, sometimes ice cubes, because I get really puffy. I'll use a simple moisturiser which I got while we were on tour in Korea and then I use the La-Roche Posay SPF. At night, I use a benzoyl peroxide between those steps, without the SPF.‚Äù On doing her own tour make-up‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI like the time to myself in that way. I slot for 20 more minutes than I actually need, just because it's nice to have an hour of the day sitting alone in a room. I value that alone time very much, and I do think it's therapeutic. I'll listen to a podcast, I like On Being with Krista Tippett. The guests that she has on are always so beautifully spoken and experts in their respective fields, and she's an excellent moderator. [For my make-up] on stage it's really about emphasising certain features, because I'm so far away from so many people. Off-stage, I use a concealer for spot treating, a blush and do my brows. I like fine highlighting powders that both set and give your face some sheen. I'm not a lipstick person so I use a brown-ish lip liner and a glossy balm. For stage, I go a bit heavier with highlighter and blush. I fill my brows in more.‚Äù On her favourite blushes‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI'm obsessed with Hourglass Unreal Liquid Blush in Vision and Scene, and the Diffused Heat powder blush. I initially wouldn't have leant into pinks like that, but it's so nice on the skin and it's really sheer.‚Äù On her signature scent‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúAnother 13 from Le Labo always makes me feel like I'm at home. Smells are so important when you're away from home to make you feel like you're back there. But when we were in Seoul, Le Labo does the city specific scent and that one is a new favourite as well.‚Äù On her bob haircut‚Ä¶ ‚ÄúI honestly feel the most like myself with shorter hair. It was off the back of, almost like a pre-break-up, when things inside start to feel a bit tangled up, and you feel like you need a change. I didn't know where to start so I cut it all off and felt so much lighter. People say hair holds memories and feelings. It felt good to sever ties where I needed to, which sounds harsh but it really was a lighter and nicer experience than that. I love it. I see pictures of myself with my long hair or I'll watch somebody else's show and they're using their hair like this extra limb, and I'll get jealous. I'll miss it sometimes, but I think overall, I feel way more like myself and in my skin with this hair. Bobby Eliot cuts it.‚Äù...

‚Äâ The power of scent is often underestimated. More than just masking odors, a carefully chosen air freshener can dramatically alter the mood and perception of a space. In fact, studies show that scent can evoke strong emotional responses and even influence memory ‚Äì a key element in creating a welcoming and memorable home environment. With a growing market ‚Äì the global air freshener market was valued at USD 6.48 billion in 2023 and is projected to reach USD 8.89 billion by 2032 (Source: Grand View Research) ‚Äì there's a wealth of options available to help you achieve a truly luxurious feel. A curated selection of premium air fresheners. (Pexels/Alesia_Kozik) Elevate Your Space: 5 Air Freshener Recommendations for a 5-Star Experience Forget simply eliminating unpleasant smells; the goal is to *curate* an atmosphere. Just as a five-star hotel meticulously considers its scent profile to enhance the guest experience, you can do the same in your home. Here are five recommendations to help you achieve that level of sophistication: 1. HMNS ‚Äì This is a Safe Space: A Sanctuary of Calm HMNS' ‚ÄúThis is a Safe Space‚Äù isn't just an air freshener; it's an olfactory experience designed to promote relaxation and well-being. Unlike customary, often overpowering scents, this fragrance focuses on subtle, grounding notes. Think of it as the equivalent of stepping into a high-end spa ‚Äì a blend of calming amber, sandalwood, and a hint of musk. It's ideal for bedrooms,living rooms,or any space where you want to foster a sense of tranquility.The brand emphasizes sustainable practices and non-toxic ingredients,appealing to the growing consumer demand for eco-conscious products. 2. Diptyque ‚Äì Baies: The Classic Luxury A perennial favorite among fragrance connoisseurs, Diptyque's Baies is synonymous with understated elegance. This iconic scent combines the sweetness of blackcurrant leaves with the floral notes of rose and jasmine. It's reminiscent of walking through a lush garden on a summer evening. While a higher price point, the longevity and complexity of the fragrance make it a worthwhile investment for those seeking a truly premium experience. 3. Jo Malone London ‚Äì Lime basil & Mandarin: A Refreshing Zest For a brighter,more invigorating atmosphere,Jo Malone London's Lime Basil & Mandarin is an excellent choice. This fragrance is a vibrant blend of citrusy lime and mandarin with herbaceous basil. It's a scent that feels both sophisticated and uplifting, akin to the ambiance of a chic boutique hotel lobby. It's especially well-suited for kitchens, bathrooms, or entryways. 4. Le Labo ‚Äì Santal 26: A Sophisticated Woodiness Le Labo's Santal 26 is a more unisex and intensely woody fragrance. It features notes of sandalwood,cedar,and amber,creating a warm and inviting atmosphere. Imagine the scent of a luxurious library or a high-end men's grooming lounge. This is a great option for those who prefer a bolder, more grounding scent profile. 5. Nest New York ‚Äì Bamboo: A serene Escape Nest New York's Bamboo offers a clean and refreshing scent inspired by the tranquility of a bamboo forest. It combines green bamboo, white orchid, and a touch of citrus.This fragrance is perfect for creating a spa-like atmosphere in bathrooms or bedrooms, evoking the feeling of a peaceful retreat. It's a lighter, more airy option compared to some of the richer, more complex fragrances on this list. Ultimately, the best air freshener for your home is a matter of personal preference.Experiment with different scents and find what resonates with you and creates the atmosphere you desire. investing in a quality fragrance can be a simple yet impactful way to transform your living space into a haven of comfort and style. In the increasingly popular world of independent perfumery, HMNS (Human Made Scents) has quickly gained a devoted following for its thoughtfully crafted and emotionally resonant fragrances. A prime example of their success is ‚ÄúThis is a Safe Space,‚Äù a limited-edition scent initially released during the brand's BCA Expoversary celebration in 2023. Due to its immediate appeal and limited production run, it has become highly sought-after, frequently selling out at both the official HMNS online store and various fragrance marketplaces. A Fragrance Designed for Tranquility ‚ÄúThis is a Safe Space‚Äù isn't simply a perfume; it's an olfactory experience designed to evoke feelings of calm, security, and renewal. The fragrance opens with a vibrant and uplifting blend of citrus notes ‚Äì zesty lemon and invigorating lime ‚Äì balanced by the delicate,soothing character of white tea. This initial impression is luminous and subtly herbaceous, reminiscent of a sun-drenched garden after a light rain. The heart of the Composition: A Breath of Fresh Air The heart of the fragrance transitions into a captivating floral and airy accord....
